headline: Maple Syrup Caramels Recipe
description: Flavored with plenty of pure maple syrup and just a hint of sea salt, these sensational (and seasonal!) caramels are simple to prepare and totally crave-worthy.
name: Maple Syrup Caramels Recipe
keywords: Edible DIY, holiday baking, maple, maple syrup

recipeInstructions.text: Line an 8-by 8-inch square baking pan with aluminum foil, leaving a 2-inch overhang on two sides. Line pan again with parchment paper, leaving overhang on alternate sides from foil. Lightly oil parchment or spray with nonstick cooking spray. Set aside.
Combine heavy cream, butter, sea salt, and maple extract (if using) in a small saucepan and bring to a boil. Immediately remove saucepan from heat and set aside.

Combine sugar, maple syrup, corn syrup, and water in a large saucepan. Bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring until sugar dissolves. Boil without stirring, swirling pan occasionally until mixture has gone from light to dark amber, about 6 minutes.

Carefully pour cream mixture into sugar mixture. It will bubble vigorously. Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer until a candy thermometer registers 248°F (120°C). Pour caramel into prepared pan. Allow caramel to cool for at least 3 hours. Cut caramel into 1-inch pieces using kitchen shears and wrap pieces in wax paper. Caramels will keep for at least a week stored in an airtight container at room temperature, and even longer in refrigerator.

review.reviewBody: I made these and would offer some suggestions. I don’t add water as it needs to boil off anyway. Just be sure to keep stirring well. Also I use molasses in place of corn syrup because I hate corn syrup. Might also try honey. Finally I cool the caramel mixture before stirring in extracts otherwise they just burn off.

Just made this a couple days ago. The texture is a bit soft for me. I might let the thermometer go up a bit more at the boiling stage, but these are very delicious, rich, and flavorful. I don't get a strong maple flavor, but the taste seems more complex than the caramels I've made that don't include it. 

For step 2, I heated the cream mixture at a very low heat until the butter melted before boiling it, and that worked well. Perhaps this bit of information will be helpful to someone else.

listen up. we have made this recipe two times. TWO FUCKING TIMES. and both turned out like absolute shit. it looked as if Dwayne "the rock" Johnson and Donald Trump had a child but while the child was in the womb Trump smoked six packs a day and only ate fried tuna. we looked at it after the whole boil shitdown and it appeared poisonous. if you listened real good you can hear it say "kill me". we gave it to our neighbors 'the ones we hate' and now their 16 year old son is in the hospital and their gerbils having a seizure. oh and don't even get me started on the taste. satan himself would make this, eat it, and declare it too evil. just imagine your middle aged uncle shit in your blender, mixed in a tablespoon of maple syrup then mixed it together, ate it, threw up, then gave it to you. over all it was pretty good, 5 stars.

These were excellent, but I need to tweak based on my ingredients. I used raw cream from a local dairy that is waaaaay heavy on the butterfat. The end result was maybe a little TOO buttery! So, next time around I might either cut the cream with some milk, or maybe cut down the butter, I don't know. Also made without maple extract, and found that they didn't have a real maple flavor, but if I can get some natural maple syrup I'll try with that.
